questiontext.text:
The convolution theorem

Let \(f(t)\) and \(g(t)\) be causal functions with Laplace transforms \(F(s)\) and \(G(s)\) respectively, i.e. \({\cal L}\{f(t)\}=F(s)\) and \({\cal L}\{g(t)\}=G(s)\). Then it can be shown that


Key Point

The Convolution Theorem

\[{\cal L}^{-1}\{F(s)G(s)\}=(f*g)(t)\qquad\text{ or equivalently}\qquad {\cal L}\{(f*g)(t)\}=F(s)G(s)\]


Example

Find the inverse transform of \(\displaystyle{{6\over {s(s^2+9)}}}\).

  1. Using partial fractions
  2. Using the convolution theorem.

Solution

  1. \(\quad\displaystyle {6\over {s(s^2+9)}}={(2/3)\over s}-{(2/3)s\over{s^2+9}}\) and so \[\begin{eqnarray*} {\cal L}^{-1}\left\{{6\over {s(s^2+9)}}\right\}= \tfrac{2}{3}{\cal L}^{-1}\left\{{1\over s}\right\}- \tfrac{2}{3}{\cal L}^{-1}\left\{{s\over {s^2+9}}\right\}= \tfrac{2}{3}u(t)-\tfrac{2}{3}\cos 3t.u(t) \end{eqnarray*}\]

  2. Let us choose \(\quad\displaystyle F(s)={2\over s}\qquad\text{ and}\qquad G(s)={3\over {s^2+9}}\) then \[f(t)={\cal L}^{-1}\{F(s)\}=2u(t)\quad \text{ and}\quad g(t)={\cal L}^{-1}\{G(s)\}=\sin 3t.u(t)\] So \[\begin{eqnarray*} {\cal L}^{-1}\{F(s)G(s)\}&=&(f*g)(t)\qquad \text{(by the convolution theorem)}\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\\&=&\int_0^t2u(t-x)\sin 3x. u(x)\,dx \end{eqnarray*}\] Now the variable \(t\) can take any value from \(-\infty\) to \(+\infty\). If \(t<0\) then the variable of integration, \(x\), is negative and so \(u(x)=0\). We conclude that \[(f*g)(t)=0\quad \text{ if}\quad t<0\] that is, \((f*g)(t)\) is a causal function. Let us now consider the other possibility for \(t\), that is the range \(t\ge 0\). Now, in the range of integration \(0\le x\le t\) and so \[u(t-x)=1\qquad u(x)=1\] since both \(t-x\) and \(x\) are non-negative. Therefore \[\begin{eqnarray*} {\cal L}^{-1}\{F(s)G(s)\}&=&\int_0^t2\sin 3x\,dx\\&=&\left[\phantom{\dfrac{1}{1}}\!\!\!-\dfrac{2}{3}\cos 3x \right]_0^t=-\dfrac{2}{3}(\cos 3t -1)\qquad t\ge 0\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad \end{eqnarray*}\] Hence \[{\cal L}^{-1}\{{6\over {s(s^2+9)}}\}=-\dfrac{2}{3}(\cos 3t -1)u(t)\] which agrees with the value obtained above using the partial fraction approach.
